intro: Geonoma camana, commonly known as the Camaná fern, is a species of flowering plant native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the family Bromeliaceae, which includes many epiphytic and terrestrial plants. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, attaching itself to tree trunks or branches in humid, shaded environments. Its leaves are long and strap-like, often arranged in a rosette pattern, and can reach lengths of up to 1 meter. Geonoma camana produces small, clustered flowers that are usually white or pale pink, contributing to its ornamental value in botanical gardens.
